Reproduced with permission16. Copyright 2018, Wiley-VCH. h Transfer characteristics curves of an edible OFET on a rigid gelatine capsule substrate. Reproduced with permission184. Copyright 2010, Wiley-VCH.

sec.title: Adhesion and conformability
sec.p: To improve the sensing accuracy of skin-like electronics, they should have good adhesion, and can adhere seamlessly to irregular, pliable, and locomotive objects1. For example, the skin-like OFETs, prepared by Bao’s group26, could be seamlessly attached on the back of the human hand (Fig. 6b).

sec.title: Easy integration
sec.p: Like human skins, the artificial skins should have an ability to discriminate various bio-signals and physical stimuli from the surrounding environment. Thus, multi-functional smart e-skin with diverse sensory modules is the future research focus (Fig. 6c)176. However, to enable high-resolution sensing, each device should be efficiently connected. Kim and coworkers177 constructed a prosthetic artificial skin to sense multiple external stimuli, including temperature, humidity, strain, and pressure.

sec.title: Low-cost and large-area manufacturing
sec.p: Low-cost and high-density sensory array is a prerequisite for commercialization and application of intelligent artificial skin and wearable electronics. Some researchers have been committed to preparing high-density flexible sensory array. For example, Pei and coworkers178 reported fully printed 10 × 6 flexible transistor arrays based on their developed water-based silver-nanowires screen-printed ink and high-resolution printed patterns of AgNWs on the PET substrate. The obtained transistor could be worn on a finger (Fig. 6d). Bao’s group179 constructed a stretchable and low-voltage synaptic transistor array with a device density of 20 device cm−2 based on the inkjet-printed method (Fig. 6e). Taking a groundbreaking step, they developed an intrinsically stretchable transistor array with an unprecedented device density of 347 transistors per square centimeter, and could endure high stretching strain up to 100% and multiple stretching cycles of 1000 with minimal degradation of carrier mobility81. These studies illustrated that the obtained high-density transistor array could be employed as a backplane for high-resolution touch sensing in the conformal e-skin.

sec.title: Self-healing
sec.p: Like human skin, artificial skins should also have an ability to repair its initial appearance and nearly original sensing capabilities after suffering from external damage180. At present, various self-healing materials have been successfully fabricated based on the introduction of healing agents and the incorporation of dynamic reversible bonds181. Both the strategies can induce the energy dissipation in polymers through bond breakage when subjected to stretching strain, while maintaining the original charge transport capability. Bao’s group16 reported a supramolecular PDMS–MPUx-IU1−x polymer film with notch-insensitive high stretchability (1200%) and autonomous self-healing even in artificial sweat (Fig. 6f). This was mainly due to the incorporation of a mixture of strong and weak dynamic crosslinking hydrogen bonds into the elastomer matrix. Based on this self-healing polymer film, they further prepared a 7 × 7 strain sensor array to precisely sense the mechanical deformations caused by external stimuli (Fig. 6g). Years later, Oh and coworkers18 incorporated chemical moieties into the conjugated polymers to increase the amorphous fraction and decrease the relative crystallinity, thereby increasing the dynamic non-covalent crosslinking of polymer semiconductor film.

sec.title: Biocompatibility and biodegradability
sec.p: Good biocompatibility ensures an intimate association between e-skins and soft body tissues, and good biodegradability ensures a spontaneous degradation of e-skins in or on human body without the additional risk associated with secondary surgeries. For organic materials, the chemical composition, surface charge, and pH value significantly impact their biocompatibility owing to the increased cytotoxicity182. PEDOT and its derivatives are desirable biocompatible materials183. The substrate, dielectric, and semiconductor materials from nature showed a great potential for enabling fully biocompatible and biodegradable organic electronics. Irimia-Vladu and coworkers184 have reported an edible OFET with good biocompatibility, biodegradability, and electrical properties using a wide range of natural materials (Fig. 6h).

sec.title: Self-powering
sec.p: The demand for persistent power consumption largely limits the practical application of e-skin. Therefore, preparing a self-powered electronic device is a significant consideration for these e-skins. Some existing electronic devices, such as solar cells, supercapacitors, wireless antennas, piezoelectric nanogenerators and triboelectric generators, have distinct advantages in self-powering application185,186.

sec.title: Summary and perspective
sec.p: In the past twenty years, a great deal of research efforts on material design, device architecture, and processing technologies have facilitated the rapid development of flexible electronics. The performance of a few reported flexible electronic systems, including displays and biosensors, has reached the same level of the rigid counterparts. Their mechanical compliance and stability can also satisfy the requirements for practical applications. However, there is still a long way to go before the extensive practical applications of FOFETs with regard to the following technical limitations and issues.

Firstly, it remains a considerable challenge to balance the electrical performance and mechanical compliance of organic semiconductors. Geometric engineering is the most commonly used strategy to increase the mechanical flexibility of organic semiconductors, but this strategy usually requires complicated manufacturing processes and is detrimental to the large-area array and integration. Blending with elastomers is considered as an efficient approach to improving the flexibility and stretchability of organic semiconductors with little of sacrifice of the electrical performance. However, current reports only involved the specific elastomers (PDMS, SEBS) and polymer semiconductors (DPP-based polymers, P3HT), and the blending mechanism is still not clear. Thus, determining the effects of blending conditions (including molecular weight, surface energy, solubility coefficient, phase separation, etc.) on hybrid polymer semiconductor can provide a clear guideline for enabling highly stretchable organic semiconductors. The crosslinking of polymer dielectrics is a feasible method to improve their stretchability and solvent tolerance. In addition, the required intrinsic flexibility and stretchability for all the components largely restrict the application of some rigid functional materials (such as perovskite with excellent light sensitivity) in the stretchable electronic devices due to their high-crystallinity nature. Therefore, how to develop a wide range of multi-functional materials with high flexibility and stretchability is a focus.

Secondly, developing large-scale, low-voltage and solution-processable organic circuits are highly desirable for flexible electronic applications. Most of the reported organic circuits is prepared with organic molecules as the active layer, whereas polymer semiconductors are rarely used in the organic circuits. Moreover, due to the lack of high-performance, air-stable n-type and ambipolar-conjugated polymers, the development of complementary organic circuits lags far behind the unipolar organic circuits. Nowadays, there are two major issues deserving to be addressed: the one is to fabricate high-performance and air-stable n-type and ambipolar polymer semiconductors for solution-processable complementary organic circuits, and the other is to construct highly flexible and stretchable organic circuitry system on ultra-thin plastic or elastomeric substrate.

Thirdly, researchers are encouraged to pioneer the application of FOFETs into complicated integrated systems and subsequent practically applicable e-skins. The commonly used device manufacturing technologies such as spin-coating and vacuum evaporation cannot meet the requirements of large-area and integrated electronic circuitry. Thus, researchers should attach their importance to develop new processing technologies, such as R2R manufacturing. Low-thickness, light weight, high-density and highly flexible electronic devices are also a significant development direction in the future. Moreover, current researches only stayed in the stretchable OFETs, but the preparation of stretchable OFET-based sensors is rarely achieved. Most stretchable OFETs reported are prepared typically based on the continuous thermal lamination-transfer procedures to avoid the solvent damage to adjacent layer. But the complicated manufacturing procedures are also detrimental to the high density and integration. For fabrication of high-performance e-skins, the crosslinking polymer layer is seen as a feasible strategy to overcome this problem.

Fourthly, to surpass the multifunctionalities of human skin and follow the advent of the era of artificial intelligence, e-skins propose higher requirements for flexible electronics and circuits, not just high flexibility and electrical characteristics. Using novel materials and developing efficient device architecture to open up more potential applications in biomedical fields is highly required. For example, how to exploit the existing materials from nature and human body (such as protein, starches and glucose) to prepare highly sensitive and easily degradable biosensors. How to enable the real-time detection of the wound by a highly sensitive, self-healing, and biocompatible OFET-based biosensors. How to integrate various types of FOFET-based biosensors into a device to achieve multivariate change detection. How to achieve a long-lasting sensing and detection for human body by preparing a self-powering FOFET-based sensors. All of these challenges give us more opportunities to explore more innovative applications for flexible electronics. We believe that the application of FOFETs and their circuits in rollable displays, smart cards, and artificial skins will be an increasingly significant interdisciplinary topic in the near future.
